intro: Sphinctanthus fluvii-dulcis, commonly known as the river-brine sedge, is a flowering plant native to specific regions in South America. It belongs to the family Cyperaceae, which includes sedges, and is characterized by its grass-like appearance with triangular stems. The plant thrives in wetland environments, often found in marshes and along riverbanks where it can tolerate fluctuating water levels. Its small, inconspicuous flowers are typically arranged in spikelets, and it plays a role in stabilizing soil in its native habitat. Due to its limited distribution, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
